Agroforestry
Notes

  • InDesign
  • Illustrator
  • Photoshop

This project came about for a couple of reasons. One of the main reasons, was new research and information had come out since some of the earliest Agroforestry Notes were written and our team wanted to update them to be more current, relevant, but most importantly - more accurate. We would also no longer be re-printing these items as they went out of stock. We found that as our online PDFs became more popular we were finding there was less of a need to print out this particular serious. However, our audience was still interested in the material, based on analytics results we studied.

Requirements

  • PDF
  • Future potential for content to be served in HTML format
  • Make more visually appealing
  • USDA Banner on cover

Research

The long-term view of this would be an item that would eventually take on a more interactive approach to the information that was delivered. I had started by looking at interactive story-telling techniques. Naturally, I came across the New York Times interactive stories - while this project wasn’t going to accomplish this yet, it was good to think how this project could eventually evolve into that.

I looked around at how news agencies and blogs delivery their information, what were consistencies across the board and what leeway did I have as a designer to make this our own.

I also looked back at all of the Agroforestry Notes from the 90s and looked at how the publication series itself evolved. I thought about what I could keep that maintained the recognition.

The department has a Design Standards document that I looked through to see if anything needed to be implemented into the new design.

The Journey

These notes were originally design to be hole-punched, stuck in a binder, and taken out to the field by resource professionals. They were black and white because it was less expensive than 4-color printing.

We were no longer bound to black and white...

We decided to continue publishing online PDFs, but thought that this was a good time to consider giving this series a bit of a face-lift.

We were no longer bound to black and white as the documents would be viewed digitally or printed out by the user themselves. There was no longer a need to saddle stitch, which required design the product to have pages in multiples of four. As I designed this ‘new’ look, I went over the various elements that I could keep. I felt this would make this update feel like an extension of the series, rather than an entirely new product.

Also to help update the look and feel of the publication I decided to use a more modern font. I chose Montserrat for the headings and Open Sans for the body copy. As these would be mostly digital documents. It made sense to incorporate sans-serif fonts for this project.

There were two main elements that I chose to put into the new template — the subtitles and the main banner. I liked the skimmability of the original template. By having the subtitles on the left hand side the reader could easy skim to the section they needed.


Final Product
